data: No rainfall to low rainfall expected

Moderate water loss
Site selection activities should begin

Site selection activities should begin 
Select a site with good water source, drainage, gentle slope rich in organic matter.
Acquire soil and cropping history of site
Field investigation activities can begin (soil nutrient analysis and field measurement)

Good condition for field activities.

Field workers are advised to radiate often.
Adequate day length for field activity
Field activities can begin early in the day
Darkness would set in early thus decreasing visibility and affecting field activities
Remain hydrated and wear protective clothing during field activities
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE LA DADEKOTOPONG DISTRICT OF THE GT ACCRA REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 29TH DEC – 1ST FEB. 2025

For the week of 29th Dec to 1st Feb 2025, expected temperature will be 26 OC (for minimum) to 34OC (maximum) with relative humidity of about 60% and low chances of rainfall (30% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for activities in line with selecting a suitable field for maize production.

Seek history of local solutions to manage prevailing pests and diseases (Fall Army Worm, stem borers and common rust disease of maize etc.) in the community
Locate the availability of agro-shops, labour and machine sources in the community.                 
Avoid gravelly and shallow soils and select deep well-drained loamy soils.
Avoid low-lying areas because they are usually poorly drained and easily get waterlogged thus reducing yield. 
Avoid planting maize in shady areas. Too many trees on the field will reduce the amount of sunlight that reaches the maize plant.
Use local ways to control pests, find nearby agro-shops in the community, plant in good soil, avoid waterlogged or shady areas, and pick fields with enough sunlight.

Land preparation activities should begin 
Secure all machinery, labour and finances needed 

Plough and harrow farmland to a fine tilth when adequate moisture is available

Include moisture and soil conservation techniques in land preparation
Construct firebelt during bush burning to avoid bushfires
Plan land preparation early in the morning or late in the afternoon when humidity levels are generally high.

Perform land preparation early in the morning or late in the afternoon to avoid exposure to intense heat
- stay hydrated and take regular breaks during field activities, especially under high sunlight
Field activity should begin very early in the morning
Field activity can extend into late afternoon
Adjust workload and complete tasks before soil moisture become unworkable
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAZIE FARMERS IN THE LA DADEKOTOPONG DISTRICT OF THE GT ACCRA REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 29TH DEC – 22ND MAR. 2025

For the period of 29th December to 22nd March 2025, expected temperature will be 26 OC (for minimum) to 34OC (maximum) with relative humidity of about 65% and low chances of rainfall (40% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for activities in line with selecting a suitable field for maize production.

Slash and leave all crop residues and weeds to decompose to conserve soil moisture and protect soil structure
Field demarcation and fencing can be executed during this time. Ploughing activities should be done when the site receives adequate rainfall.   
Practice no or minimum tillage.
Leave crop residues/weeds to decompose for soil moisture. Do field fencing and plough after rain. Use no or minimal tillage to protect soil

Germination Test
Choose a suitable maize variety
Determine the germination percentage of seed ( > 80% acceptable)
Plant seeds after adequate rainfall
Target plant population of 25,000 – 26,000 plants per acre 
Ensure adequate soil moisture for germination
There will be suitable temperature to support germination and seedling growth
There will be adequate air moisture to support germination and seedling growth
There will be suitable sunlight and energy to support germination and seedling growth
Field activity should begin very early in the morning
Field activity can extend into late afternoon
Soil moisture must be monitored regularly to ensure adequate soil moisture availability
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE LA DADEKOTOPON DISTRICT OF THE GT ACCRA REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 23RD MAR – 17TH  MAY. 2025

For the week of 23rd March to 17th May 2025, expected temperature will be 25 OC (for minimum) to 33OC (maximum) with relative humidity of about 80% and high chances of rainfall (60% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for planting / sowing activities for maize production

Select maize variety based on weather forecast and site location
Conduct germination test 7 days before sowing to ensure seed viability (≥ 80%)
Plant at the start of the rainy season for good germination and plant establishment. Delayed planting may affect yields.
Plant treated seeds in rows at recommended spacing (25,000 to 26,000 plants/acre) as advised by Extension officers or seed producer
Intercrop plant with legumes in rows midway between maize rows when intercropped
Pick maize variety based on weather. Test seeds for germination 7 days before sowing. Plant at the start of rainy season, use treated seeds in rows, and intercrop with legumes for better yields.

Fertilizer Application
Select fertilizer based on maize variety, ecological zone and cultural practice adopted
Apply 3 bags of NPK at 5cm away from each plant at planting or within 2 weeks of germination
Organic and foliar fertilizers can be added as supplementary nutrition to boost plant growth and yields
Apply fertilizers when day temperatures are low
- Adequate air and soil moisture will be available for fertilizer application

- High ligh and heat intensity would affect fertilizer application
- Apply fertilizers early morning or later afternoon
- Start late afternnon fertilizer application from 4pm
Ensure there is adequate soil moisture for granular fertilizer to dissolve in the soil
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE LA DADEKOTOPON DISTRICT OF THE GT ACCRA REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 22rd MAR – 17th May, 2025

For the week of 23rd March to 17th May 2025, expected temperature will be 25 OC (for minimum) to 33OC (maximum) with relative humidity of about 80% and high chances of rainfall (60% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for planting / sowing activities for maize production


Use fertilizers recommended for specific agro-ecological zones, variety potential, cropping history, soil type, soil moisture, cultural practices, and soil fertility.
Apply recommended quantities and rates for maximum benefits by burying fertilizer 5cm away from plants.
Basic fertilizer required is 3 bags (50kg) of NPK per acre.
NPK rate: 5g per plant at planting or within 14 days after germination with adequate soil moisture.
Apply foliar (liquid) fertilizers during late vegetative and early grain-fill stages to improve yields and seed/grain quality.
Follow product instructions and use foliar fertilizers to supplement, not replace, compound fertilizers
Use zone-specific fertilizers. Apply 3 bags NPK/acre, 5g/plant at planting. Bury 5cm from plants. Use foliar fertilizers late in growth. Follow instructions for best results

Weed Control
High rainfall would promote rapid weed growth 
Spray appropriate weedicide at least 3 hours before and after it rains to ensure effectiveness
Manual weeding should be done a few hours after rains when soil is moist
High rainfall affects pest movement and growth hence applying insecticide at least 3 hours before or after rains is encouraged

-High temperature promote rapid weed and pest development

Control weeds before they flower and produce seeds

-Higher humidity promote weed growth

Regular weeding to keep weed growth below threshhold

-The high soil moisture promote weed growth

Regular weeding to keep weed growth below threshhold

High soil temperature would encourage pest activities in the soil 
Scott field and soil regularly and apply appropriate pesticide to keep pest population in check

-Long day light and sun intensity encourage active pest activity and disease spread 
Intensify scotting activity during the vegetative and grain prodction stage to avoid yield loss

Pests and disease activity and damage on crop would begin very early in the day

Pesticides application should begin by 5;30am

Pests and diseases activities become active during the late aftering and evening

Spray contact insectide after 4pm to have effective results
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE LA DADEKOTOPONG DISTRICT OF THE GT ACCRA REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 20TH APR – 17TH MAY, 2025

For the week of 20th April to 17th May 2025, expected temperature will be 26 OC (for minimum) to 33OC (maximum) with relative humidity of about 67% and moderate chances of rainfall (60% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for weed management activities.

Start regular scouting for presence of weeds/pests/diseases or symptoms two weeks after germination
Identify weeds, pests and diseases in the field and establish control thresholds.
Manage weeds within the first 6 weeks of growth or before they produce flowers/seeds.
Practice intercropping and crop rotation to prevent weed, pest and disease build-up.
Employ manual, mechanical, biological, or chemical methods to control weeds, pests and diseases
Use appropriate implements or recommended herbicides, pesticides and fungicides to manage weed/pest and disease spread.
Avoid continuous use of chemicals or products with similar active ingredients to reduce resistance.
Key pests and vectors to scout for include fall armyworm, Africa armyworm, stem borers and leaf hoppers.
Identify weeds/pests/diseases 2 weeks after planting. Control weeds early, rotate crops, and use manual/chemical methods. Avoid overusing chemicals to prevent resistance.
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE LA DADEKOTOPONG DISTRICT OF THE GT ACCRA REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 18TH MAY – 14TH JUNE, 2025
Apply fertilizers when day temperatures are low
- Adequate air and soil moisture will be available for fertilizer application

High or adequate soil moisture is required to dissolve the fertilizer into solution
Apply fertilizers early morning or later afternoon

High soil temperature promotes urea volatility from the soil
pest activities in the soil 
Scott field and soil regularly and apply appropriate pesticide to keep pest population in check

- High ligh and heat intensity would affect fertilizer application
- Apply fertilizers early morning or later afternoon
- Start late afternoon fertilizer application from 4pm
Ensure there is adequate soil moisture for granular fertilizer to dissolve in the soil
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE LA DADEKOTOPONG DISTRICT OF THE GT ACCRA REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 18TH MAY – 14TH JUNE, 2025

For the week of 18th May to 14th June 2025, expected temperature will be 25 OC (for minimum) to 32OC (maximum) with relative humidity of about 70% and low chances of rainfall (70% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for activities in line with selecting a suitable field for maize production

Use fertilizers recommended for specific agro-ecological zones, variety potential, cropping history, soil type, soil moisture, cultural practices, and soil fertility.
Apply recommended quantities and rates for maximum benefits by burying fertilizer 5cm away from plants.
Basic fertilizer required is 1bag (50kg) of urea per acre.
Urea rate: 5g per plant 4-5 weeks after germination as top-dressing.
Foliar (liquid) and organic fertilizers supply nutrients and improve soil physical characteristics. 
Apply during late vegetative and early grain-fill stages to improve yields and seed/grain quality.
Follow product instructions and use foliar (liquid) fertilizers to supplement, not replace, compound fertilizers.
Use zone-specific fertilizers. Apply 1 bag urea/acre, 5g/plant 4-5 weeks after germination. Use foliar/organic fertilizers late in growth to boost yields and soil health

Weed Control High rainfall would promote rapid weed growth 
Spray appropriate weedicide at least 3 hours before and after it rains to ensure effectiveness
Manual weeding should be done a few hours after rains when soil is moist
High rainfall affects pest movement and growth hence applying insecticide at least 3 hours before or after rains is encouraged

-High temperature promote rapid weed and pest development

Control weeds before they flower and produce seeds

-Higher humidity promote weed growth

Regular weeding to keep weed growth below threshold

-The high soil moisture promotes weed growth

Regular weeding to keep weed growth below threshold

High soil temperature would encourage pest activities in the soil 
Scott field and soil regularly and apply appropriate pesticide to keep pest population in check

-Long day light and sun intensity encourage active pest activity and disease spread 

Intensify scotting activity during the vegetative and grain production stage to avoid yield loss

Pests and disease activity and damage on crop would begin very early in the day

Pesticides application should begin by 5;30am

Spray contact insectide after 4pm to have effective results

OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE LA DADEKOTOPONG DISTRICT OF THE GT ACCRA REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 20th APRIL – 14TH JUNE, 2024

For the week of 20th April to 14th June 2025, expected temperature will be 26 OC (for minimum) to 33OC (maximum) with relative humidity of about 67% and low chances of rainfall (70% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for activities in line with selecting a suitable field for maize production

Start regular scouting for presence of weeds/pests/diseases or symptoms two weeks after germination
Identify weeds, pests and diseases in the field and establish control thresholds.
Manage weeds within the first 6 weeks of growth or before they produce flowers/seeds.
Practice intercropping and crop rotation to prevent weed, pest and disease build-up.
Employ manual, mechanical, biological, or chemical methods to control weeds, pests and diseases
Use appropriate implements or recommended herbicides, pesticides and fungicides to manage weed/pest and disease spread.
Avoid continuous use of chemicals or products with similar active ingredients to reduce resistance.
Key pests and vectors to scout for include fall armyworm, Africa armyworm, stem borers and leaf hoppers.
Scout for weeds/pests/diseases 2 weeks after planting. Control weeds early, rotate crops, and use manual/chemical methods. Avoid overusing chemicals to prevent resistance.
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE LA DADEKOTOPON DISTRICT OF THE GT ACCRA REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 15TH JUNE – 9TH AUGUST 2025

For the week of 15th June to 9th August 2025, expected temperature will be 23OC (for minimum) to 29OC (maximum) with relative humidity of about 75% and high chances of rainfall (80% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for harvesting activities of maize production

Harvest maize at physiological maturity based on variety and market demand (fresh or dried).
Physiological maturity is indicated by a white creamy fluid when a kernel tip is broken (approx. 32% moisture).
Harvest dried maize when grain moisture content is between 15% and 13%.
Promptly remove harvested maize from the field to prevent quality degradation, burning, insect infestation, aflatoxin contamination, and market value loss.
Safely transport maize using head portals, tractors, and trucks.
Harvest maize at maturity (32% moisture for fresh, 13-15% for dried). Remove quickly to avoid pests, aflatoxin, and quality loss. Transport safely using proper methods.
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE LA DADEKOTOPON DISTRICT OF THE GT ACCRA REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 13TH JULY – 6TH SEPT, 2025

For the week of 13th July to 6th Sept 2025, expected temperature will be 24 OC (for minimum) to 28OC (maximum) with relative humidity of about 78% and low chances of rainfall (60% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for postharvest activities for maize production

Dry harvested maize (small quantity) on concrete compounds, fertilizer bags, polyethylene or tarpaulins sheets. 
Ensure that maize grains are properly dried without debris and insects (larger grain borers and weevils) before storage
Dry maize grains to 12-13% moisture content before storage to prevent fungal infections and toxin production.
Store untreated maize for 2-3 months to prevent insect re-infestation.
Treat dried grains with recommended insecticide and store in maize cribs, jute or polypropylene sacks.
For long storage, dehusk and or shell, and treat maize grains with insecticide prior to storage in cribs, silos or PICs-bags. 
Use aluminium phosphide 56% (Phostoxin, Temaphos, Celphos P, Bextoxin, Agroxin Tablet). Rate: 3 tablets per tonne (10 maxi bags).  Re-entry- 4 days after application.
Regularly inspect treated/untreated stored grains to ensure quality is maintained during the storage period
Dry maize on clean surfaces to 12-13% moisture. Store untreated for 2-3 months. Treat grains with insecticide for long storage. Regularly check stored grains for quality.

Select a low land and valleys that have good water holding capacity and not of too much of stumps. Know the history of the land regarding pests and disease prevalence.                 
Avoid gravelly and shallow soils and select deep well-drained loamy soils.
Select a good land with good waterholding capacity and rich in soil nutrients and free of pests and diseases.

Slash and leave all crop residues and slashed weeds to decompose to conserve soil moisture and protect soil structure
Field demarcation and fencing can be executed during this time. Ploughing activities should be done when the site receives adequate rainfall.   
Practice no or minimum tillage.

High moisture loss would affect the efficacy of the chemicals used

Spray appropriate chemical early Morning or late afternoon to reduce moisture loss and ensure effective action

OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR RICE FARMERS IN THE BIAKOYE DISTRICT OF THE OTI REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 20th APRIL – 14TH JUNE, 2024

For the week of 20th April to 14th June 2025, expected temperature will be 26°C (for minimum) to 33°C (maximum) with relative humidity of about 67% and low chances of rainfall (70% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for activities in line with selecting a suitable field for rice production

Start regular scouting for presence of weeds/pests/diseases or symptoms two weeks after germination
Identify weeds, pests and diseases in the field and establish control thresholds.
Manage weeds within the first 6 weeks of growth or before they produce flowers/seeds.
Practice intercropping and crop rotation to prevent weed, pest and disease build-up.
Employ manual, mechanical, biological, or chemical methods to control weeds, pests and diseases
Use appropriate implements or recommended herbicides, pesticides and fungicides to manage weed/pest and disease spread.
Avoid continuous use of chemicals or products with similar active ingredients to reduce resistance.
Key pests and vectors to scout for include fall armyworm, Africa armyworm, stem borers and leaf hoppers.
Scout for weeds/pests/diseases 2 weeks after planting. Control weeds early, rotate crops, and use manual/chemical methods. Avoid overusing chemicals to prevent resistance.
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE BIAKOYE DISTRICT OF THE OTI REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 15TH JUNE – 9TH AUGUST 2025

For the week of 15th June to 9th August 2025, expected temperature will be 23°C (for minimum) to 29°C (maximum) with relative humidity of about 75% and high chances of rainfall (80% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for harvesting activities of maize production

Harvest maize at physiological maturity based on variety and market demand (fresh or dried).
Physiological maturity is indicated by a white creamy fluid when a kernel tip is broken (approx. 32% moisture).
Harvest dried maize when grain moisture content is between 15% and 13%.
Promptly remove harvested maize from the field to prevent quality degradation, burning, insect infestation, aflatoxin contamination, and market value loss.
Safely transport maize using head portals, tractors, and trucks.
Harvest maize at maturity (32% moisture for fresh, 13-15% for dried). Remove quickly to avoid pests, aflatoxin, and quality loss. Transport safely using proper methods.
OVERALL SUMMARY WEATHER OUTLOOK & ADVISORY FOR MAIZE FARMERS IN THE BIAKOYE DISTRICT OF THE OTI REGION FOR THE WEEK OF 13TH JULY – 6TH SEPT, 2025

For the week of 13th July to 6th Sept 2025, expected temperature will be 24°C (for minimum) to 28°C (maximum) with relative humidity of about 78% and low chances of rainfall (60% chance), the weather conditions will be favorable for postharvest activities for maize production

Dry harvested maize (small quantity) on concrete compounds, fertilizer bags, polyethylene or tarpaulins sheets. 
Ensure that maize grains are properly dried without debris and insects (larger grain borers and weevils) before storage
Dry maize grains to 12-13% moisture content before storage to prevent fungal infections and toxin production.
Store untreated maize for 2-3 months to prevent insect re-infestation.
Treat dried grains with recommended insecticide and store in maize cribs, jute or polypropylene sacks.
For long storage, dehusk and or shell, and treat maize grains with insecticide prior to storage in cribs, silos or PICs-bags. 
Use aluminium phosphide 56% (Phostoxin, Temaphos, Celphos P, Bextoxin, Agroxin Tablet). Rate: 3 tablets per tonne (10 maxi bags).  Re-entry- 4 days after application.
Regularly inspect treated/untreated stored grains to ensure quality is maintained during the storage period
Dry maize on clean surfaces to 12-13% moisture. Store untreated for 2-3 months. Treat grains with insecticide for long storage. Regularly check stored grains for quality.
